sen.j: 金戒光明寺（こんかいこうみょうじ）は京都市左京区黒谷町にある浄土宗の寺院。
sen.e: Konkai Komyo-ji Temple is a Jodo (Pure Land) Sect temple located in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Konkai Komyo-ji Temple is a Jodo (Pure Land) Sect temple located in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Konkai Komyo-ji Temple is a Jodo (Pure Land) Sect temple located in Kurodani-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 山号は紫雲山。
sen.e: Sango (temple's title) is Mt. Shiun.
Its sango (temple's title) is Mt. Shiun.
Its sango (temple's title) is Mt. Shiun.

sen.j: 本尊は阿弥陀如来。
sen.e: Honzon (principal object of worship at a temple) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).
Its honzon (principal object of worship at a temple) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).
Its honzon (principal object of worship at a temple) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata).

sen.j: 通称寺名をくろ谷さん（くろたにさん）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The temple is usually called "Kurotani-san".
The temple is usually called "Kurotani-san".
The temple is usually called "Kurotani-san."
sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を調整

sen.j: 知恩院とならぶ格式を誇る浄土宗の大本山の1つである。
sen.e: It is one of prestigious daihonzan (head temple of a Buddhist sect) of Jodo Sect along with Chion-in Temple.
It is one of prestigious daihonzan (head temple of a Buddhist sect) of Jodo Sect along with Chion-in Temple.
It is one of prestigious daihonzan (head temple of a Buddhist sect) of Jodo Sect along with Chion-in Temple.

sen.j: 承安 (日本)5年（1175年）春、法然が比叡山の黒谷を下った。
sen.e: In Spring of 1175, Honen was descending from Kurodani in Mt. Hiei.
In Spring of 1175, Honen descended from Kurodani in Mt. Hiei.
In Spring of 1175, Honen descended from Kurodani in Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: その後岡を歩くと、大きな石があり、法然はそこに腰掛けた。
sen.e: Later when he was walking the hills, he found a large stone on which he sat down.
After that, taking a walk over the hills, Honen found a large stone and sat down there.
sen.cmt: later when → after thatwalking the hill → walking over the hillhe found a large stone on which he sat down → Honen found a large stone and sat down there.
sen.e: After that, taking a walk over the hills, Honen found a large stone and sat down there.

sen.j: するとその石から紫の雲が立ち上り、大空を覆い、西の空には、金色の光が放たれた。
sen.e: Then a purple cloud rose from the stone, covered the sky, and a golden light appeared in the western sky.
Then a purple cloud rose from the stone, covered the sky, and a golden light was cast over the western sky.
sen.cmt: a golden light appeared in the western sky → a golden light was cast over the western sky
sen.e: Then a purple cloud rose from the stone, covered the sky, and a golden light was cast over the western sky.

sen.j: そこで、法然はここに草庵を結んだ。
sen.e: Seeing all this, he built a thatched hut there.
Seeing all this, Honen built a thatched hut there.
Seeing all this, Honen built a thatched hut there.

sen.j: これがこの寺の始まりであるとされる。
sen.e: This is said to be the beginning of the temple.
This is said to be the beginning of the temple.
This is said to be the beginning of the temple.

sen.j: ここは、「白川の禅房」と呼ばれ、もとは比叡山黒谷の所領で、叡空入滅の時、黒谷の本房と白川の本房を法然に与えた。
sen.e: This place was called "Zen temple of Shira-kawa River" and was originally a territory of Kurodani, Mt. Hiei; when Eiku entered nirvana, the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa were given to Honen.

This place was called "Zen temple of Shira-kawa River" and was originally a territory of Kurodani, Mt. Hiei; when Eiku entered nirvana, the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa were given to Honen.

This place was called 'Zen temple of Shira-kawa River' and was originally a territory of Kurodani, Mt. Hiei; when Eiku entered nirvana, the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa were given to Honen.

sen.j: そのため比叡山の黒谷を元黒谷、岡崎の地を新黒谷と呼んた。
sen.e: As such, Kurodani in Mt. Hiei was called Moto (original) Kurodani, and the land of Okazaki was called Shin (new) Kurodani.
As such, Kurodani in Mt. Hiei was called Moto (original) Kurodani, and the land of Okazaki was called Shin (new) Kurodani.
As such, Kurodani in Mt. Hiei was called Moto (original) Kurodani, and the land of Okazaki was called Shin (new) Kurodani.

sen.j: 後に法然は信空に黒谷の本房と白川の本房を与え、信空はこの地に住んだ。
sen.e: Later Honen gave the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa to Shinku, and Shinku lived in this place.
Later Honen gave the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa to Shinku, and Shinku lived in this land.
sen.cmt: in this place → in this landただし、in this landが具体的にどこを指すのかが不明瞭かもしれません。
sen.e: Later Honen gave the main temple in Kurodani and the main temple in Shirakawa to Shinku, and Shinku lived in this land.

sen.j: その後岡崎の地を新黒谷とは呼ばず、黒谷（くろだに）と呼ぶようになる。
sen.e: More years later, the land of Okazaki ceased to be called Shin Kurodani and came to be called Kurodani.
More years later, the land of Okazaki ceased to be called Shin Kurodani and came to be called Kurodani.
More years later, the land of Okazaki ceased to be called Shin Kurodani and came to be called Kurodani.

sen.j: なお比叡山では黒谷を現在も青龍寺 (大津市坂本)と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Mt. Hiei, Kurodani is still called Seiryu-ji Temple (Sakamoto, Otsu City) today.
In Mt. Hiei, Kurodani is still called Seiryu-ji Temple (Sakamoto, Otsu City) today.
In Mt. Hiei, Kurodani is still called Seiryu-ji Temple (Sakamoto, Otsu City) today.

sen.j: 第5世恵顗の時に堂を整え、法然の見た縁起にちなみ紫雲山光明寺と号した。
sen.e: A hall was structured during the time of the fifth-generation head priest, Eke, and the temple was named Komyo-ji Temple of Mt. Shiun in association with an omen observed by Honen.
A hall was structured during the time of the fifth-generation head priest, Eke, and the temple was named Komyo-ji Temple of Mt. Shiun in association with the omen observed by Honen.
sen.cmt: an omen observed by Honen → the omen observed by Honen
sen.e: A hall was structured during the time of the fifth-generation head priest, Eke, and the temple was named Komyo-ji Temple of Mt. Shiun in association with the omen observed by Honen.

sen.j: 第8世運空は後光厳天皇に戒を授けて、金戒の二字を賜り、金戒光明寺と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: The eighth-generation head priest, Unku, bestowed commandments to Emperor Gokogon and was granted the two characters of 金 (kon) and 戒 (kai); thus the temple came to be called Konkai Komyo-ji Temple.
The eighth-generation head priest, Unku, bestowed commandments to Emperor Gokogon and was granted the two characters of 金 (kon) and 戒 (kai); thus the temple came to be called Konkai Komyo-ji Temple.
The eighth-generation head priest, Unku, bestowed commandments to Emperor Gokogon and was granted the two characters of 金 (kon) and 戒 (kai); thus the temple came to be called Konkai Komyo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 法然が最初に浄土宗を布教を行った地であることに因み、後小松天皇から「浄土真宗最初門」の勅額を賜った。
sen.e: In association of the land being the first place where Honen propagated Jodo Sect, an imperial scroll of "the first gate of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)" was granted by Emperor Gokomatsu.

To commemorate the fact that the land was the first place where Honen propagated Jodo Sect, Emperor Gokomatsu granted the temple an imperial scroll of "the first gate of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)."

To commemorate the fact that the land was the first place where Honen propagated Jodo Sect, Emperor Gokomatsu granted the temple an imperial scroll of 'the first gate of Jodo Shinshu' (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 江戸時代初期に城郭構造に改修された。
sen.e: Renovation work for a castle-style structure was done during the early Edo period.
The temple was renovated into a castle-style structure during the early Edo period.
The temple was converted into a castle-like structure during the early Edo period.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）京都守護職の本陣となった。
sen.e: In 1862, the temple became the headquarters for Kyoto shugoshoku (military governor of Kyoto).
In 1862, the temple became the headquarters for Kyoto shugoshoku (military governor of Kyoto).
In 1862, the temple became the headquarters for Kyoto shugoshoku (military governor of Kyoto).

sen.j: 第二次大戦後「黒谷浄土宗」として一派独立するが現在は浄土宗に合流し七大本山の一翼を担う。
sen.e: In the post World War II, it attained independence as a subsect of Jodo Sect called "Kurodani Jodo Sect", but today it has merged into Jodo Sect and has become one the Seven Major Daihonzan.
After World War II, it attained independence as a subsect of Jodo Sect called "Kurodani Jodo Sect", but today it has merged into Jodo Sect and has been playing a part in the Seven Major Daihonzan.
sen.cmt: In the post World War II, → After World War II,has become one the Seven Major Daihonzan → has been playing a part in the Seven Major Daihonzan.
sen.e: After World War II, it attained independence as a subsect of Jodo Sect called 'Kurodani Jodo Sect,' but today it has merged into Jodo Sect and has been playing a part in the Seven Major Daihonzan.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション、カンマ調整

sen.j: 御詠歌「池の水ひとの心に似たりけり 濁り澄むこと定めなければ」
sen.e: Goeika (a Buddhist hymn): "Ikenomizu Hitonokokoroni Nitarikeri Nigorizumukoto Sadamenakereba" (The water in river resembles a person's mind in that it becomes muddy at times and clear at other times without any patterns)

Goeika (a Buddhist hymn): "Ikenomizu Hitonokokoroni Nitarikeri Nigorizumukoto Sadamenakereba" (The water in river resembles a person's mind in that it becomes muddy at times and clear at other times without any patterns)

Goeika (a Buddhist hymn): "Ikenomizu Hitonokokoroni Nitarikeri Nigorizumukoto Sadamenakereba" (The water in river resembles a person's mind in that it becomes muddy at times and clear at other times without any patterns)

sen.j: 京都守護職本陣
sen.e: Headquarters of Kyoto shugoshoku
Headquarters of Kyoto shugoshoku
Headquarters of Kyoto shugoshoku

sen.j: 金戒光明寺は徳川初期に同じ浄土宗の知恩院とともに城郭構造に改められていた。
sen.e: In the early years of Tokugawa regime, the structure of Komyo-ji Temple was renovated to a castle-style along with Chion-in Temple which was also of Jodo Sect.
In the early years of Tokugawa regime, the structure of Komyo-ji Temple was renovated to a castle-style along with Chion-in Temple which also belonged to Jodo Sect.
sen.cmt: Chion-in Temple which was also of Jodo Sect. → Chion-in Temple which also belonged to Jodo Sect
sen.e: In the early years of Tokugawa regime, the structure of Komyo-ji Temple was renovated to a castle-style along with Chion-in Temple which also belonged to Jodo Sect.

sen.j: 会津藩主松平容保公が幕末の文久2年閏8月1日（1862年9月24日）に京都守護職に就任すると、京都守護職会津藩の本陣となり、藩兵1,000人が京都に常駐し1年おきに交替した。
sen.e: When on September 24, 1862 the Lord of Aizu Domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, was appointed to the post of Kyoto shugoshoku, the temple became the headquarters for Aizu Domain of Kyoto shugoshoku; 1,000 samurai warriors were always stationed in Kyoto and replaced every two years.

When on September 24, 1862 the Lord of Aizu Domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, was appointed to the post of Kyoto shugoshoku, the temple became the headquarters for Aizu Domain of Kyoto shugoshoku; 1,000 samurai warriors were always stationed in Kyoto and replaced every two years.

When on September 24, 1862 the Lord of Aizu Domain, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, was appointed to the post of Kyoto shugoshoku, the temple became the headquarters for Aizu Domain of Kyoto shugoshoku; 1,000 samurai warriors were always stationed in Kyoto and replaced every two years.

sen.j: 会津藩士のみでは手が回りきらなかったため、守護職御預かりとして新選組をその支配下に置き治安の維持に当たらせた。
sen.e: Since the feudal retainers of the Aizu clan could not handle all the work by themselves, Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate) was stationed under their control as being in custody of shugoshoku, and to attend to maintenance of security.

Since the feudal retainers of the Aizu clan could not handle all the work by themselves, Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate) was stationed under their control as being in custody of shugoshoku, and to attend to maintenance of security.

Since the feudal retainers of the Aizu clan could not handle all the work by themselves, Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate) was stationed under their control as being in custody of shugoshoku, and to attend to maintenance of security.

sen.j: 慶応3年12月9日（1868年1月3日）、この年の10月に行われた大政奉還後の王政復古の大号令によって薩摩藩・長州藩が京都市中の支配権を確立したため、京都守護職は設置後6年をもって廃止された。
sen.e: On January 3, 1868, with the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule issued in October of the same year, Satsuma and Choshu Domains established dominion over the inside Kyoto City; as a result, Kyoto shugoshoku was abolished after six years of establishment.

On January 3, 1868, with the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule issued in October of the same year, Satsuma and Choshu Domains established dominion over the inside Kyoto City; as a result, Kyoto shugoshoku was abolished six years after its establishment.
sen.cmt: with the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule → with the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Ruleabolished after six years of establishment → abolished six years after its establishment
sen.e: On January 3, 1868, with the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule issued in October of the same year, Satsuma and Choshu Domains established dominion over the inside Kyoto City; as a result, Kyoto shugoshoku was abolished six years after its establishment.

sen.j: ここ黒谷の地で、鳥羽・伏見の戦いで戦死した会津藩士の菩提を弔っている。
sen.e: In this land of Kurodani, prayers are offered to Buddha for the happiness of the dead who were killed in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.
In this land of Kurodani, memorial services are held to console the spirits of the victims who were killed in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.
In this land of Kurodani, memorial services are held to console the spirits of the feudal retainers of the Aizu clan, who were killed in the Battle of Toba-Fushimi.

sen.j: このころ中間として出入りしていた侠客が「会津の小鉄」（会津小鉄 (幕末)）である。
sen.e: The kyokaku (a professional gambler in the Edo period) who was hanging out as chugen (a rank below common soldier) around this time was "Aizu no Kotetsu" (Senkichi KOSAKA).
The kyokaku (a professional gambler in the Edo period) who was hanging out as chugen (a rank below common soldier) around this time was "Aizu no Kotetsu" (Senkichi KOSAKA).
The kyokaku (a professional gambler in the Edo period) who was hanging out as chugen (a rank below common soldier) around this time was 'Aizu no Kotetsu' (Senkichi KOSAKA).

sen.j: 御影堂（みえいどう）
sen.e: Miei-do Hall
Miei-do Hall
Miei-do Hall

sen.j: - 大殿（だいでん）とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called Daiden (Great Hall).
It is also called Daiden (Great Hall).
It is also called Daiden (Great Hall).

sen.j: 法然75歳時の肖像（坐像）を安置。
sen.e: A portrait (seated statue) of Honen at the age of seventy-five was enshrined here.
A portrait (seated statue) of Honen at the age of seventy-five was enshrined here.
A portrait (seated statue) of Honen at the age of seventy-five was enshrined here.

sen.j: 昭和9年、火災により焼失昭和19年（1944年）に再建。
sen.e: It was destructed by fire in 1934 and was rebuilt in 1944.
The hall was destructed by fire in 1934 and was rebuilt in 1944.
sen.cmt: It → The hall前に文章があるため、代名詞itの指すものが法然の肖像と解釈されると思い、the hallとしました。
sen.e: The hall was destructed by fire in 1934 and was rebuilt in 1944.

sen.j: 山門
sen.e: San-mon gate (temple gate)
San-mon gate (temple gate)
San-mon gate (temple gate)

sen.j: - 応仁の乱で焼失。
sen.e: It was destructed by fire during the Onin War.
It was destructed by fire during the Onin War.
It was destructed by fire during the Onin War.

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年）に再建。
sen.e: It was rebuilt in 1860.
It was rebuilt in 1860.
It was rebuilt in 1860.

sen.j: 後小松天皇の「浄土真宗最初門」の額がかかる。
sen.e: The frame of "the first gate of Jodo Shishu Sect" by emperor Gokomatsu was hung here.
The frame of "the first gate of Jodo Shishu Sect" by emperor Gokomatsu was hung here.
The frame of 'the first gate of Jodo Shishu Sect' by emperor Gokomatsu was hung here.

sen.j: 阿弥陀堂
sen.e: Amida-do Hall
Amida-do Hall
Amida-do Hall

sen.j: - 慶長10年（1612年）豊臣秀頼が再建した。
sen.e: It was rebuilt by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in 1612.
It was rebuilt by order of Hideyori TOYOTOMI in 1612.
sen.cmt: by Hideyori TOYOTOMI → by order of Hideyori TOYOTOMI
sen.e: It was rebuilt by order of Hideyori TOYOTOMI in 1612.

sen.j: 文殊塔（三重塔）（重要文化財）
sen.e: Monju-to Pagoda (a three-story pagoda) (important cultural property)
Monju-to Pagoda (a three-story pagoda) (important cultural property)
Monju-to Pagoda (a three-story pagoda) (important cultural property)
It was built in 1633.
It was built in 1633.
It was built in 1633.

sen.j: 本尊文殊菩薩と脇侍像を安置する（これらの像は運慶作と伝えられるが実際の作者は不明）。
sen.e: Honzon Monju Bosatsu (Manjusri Bodhisattva associated with wisdom, doctrine and awareness) and wakii-zo (statutes of attendants) were enshrined here (although these statutes are said to be Unkei's works, the actual artist remains unclear).

Honzon Monju Bosatsu (Manjusri Bodhisattva associated with wisdom, doctrine and awareness) and wakii-zo (statutes of attendants) were enshrined here (although these statutes are said to be Unkei's works, the actual artist remains unclear).

Honzon Monju Bosatsu (Manjusri Bodhisattva associated with wisdom, doctrine and awareness) and wakii-zo (statutes of attendants) were enshrined here (although these statutes are said to be Unkei's works, the actual artist remains unclear).

sen.j: 大方丈
sen.e: Ohojo (large guest house of a temple)
Ohojo (large guest house of a temple)
Ohojo (large guest house of a temple)

sen.j: - 昭和9年、火災により焼失昭和19年（1944年）に再建。
sen.e: It was destructed by fire in 1934 and rebuilt in 1944.
It was destructed by fire in 1934 and rebuilt in 1944.
It was destructed by fire in 1934 and rebuilt in 1944.

sen.j: 院内塔頭 紫雲山蓮池院
sen.e: Innai Tatchu (sub-temple): Hasuike-in Temple in Mt. Shiun
Innai Tatchu (sub-temple): Hasuike-in Temple in Mt. Shiun
Innai Tatchu (sub-temple): Hasuike-in Temple in Mt. Shiun

sen.j: - 熊谷次郎直実が出家し、熊谷直実となり、庵を結んだ場所。
sen.e: The place where Jiro Naozane KUMAGAI, who entered priesthood and became Naozane KUMAGAI, built his hermitage.
The place where Jiro Naozane KUMAGAI, who entered priesthood and became Naozane KUMAGAI, built his hermitage.
The place where Jiro Naozane KUMAGAI, who entered priesthood and became Naozane KUMAGAI, built his hermitage.

sen.j: 蓮生は建永元年8月（1206年）翌2月8日に極楽浄土に生まれると、予告往生の高札を武蔵村岡の市に立てたが果たせず、京都に戻り、ここ東山の草庵で、承元2年9月14日（1208年10月25日）に往生したと「吾妻鏡」にある（別説あり）。
sen.e: According to "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), in September of 1206, he set a notice board in a town in Musashimuraoka forecasting his rebirth that he will be born in Gokuraku Jodo (the Amida Pure Land), but it was not realized; he returned to Kyoto and passed away on October 25, 1208 in this thutched hut of Mt. Higashi (although there are other theories as well).

According to "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East), in September of 1206, Rensho set a notice board in a town in Musashimuraoka predicting his death in the near future and rebirth in Gokuraku Jodo (the Amida Pure Land), but the prediction failed; he returned to Kyoto and passed away on October 25, 1208 in this thatched hut of Mt. Higashi (although there are other theories as well).
sen.cmt: He → Rensho ただし、「蓮生」という名前について、この文章より前に説明がないので、翻訳者の翻訳した通り、「He」のままにした方がよいのかもしれません。forecasting his rebirth that he will be born in Gokuraku Jodo → predicting his death in the near future and rebirth in Gokuraku Jodo it was not realized → the prediction failedthutched hut → thatched hat
sen.e: According to 'Azuma Kagami' (The Mirror of the East), in September of 1206, Rensho set a notice board in a town in Musashimuraoka predicting his death in the near future and rebirth in Gokuraku Jodo (the Amida Pure Land), but the prediction failed; he returned to Kyoto and passed away on October 25, 1208 in this thatched hut of Mt. Higashi (although there are other theories as well).

sen.j: 通称寺の名称を熊谷堂と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Usually the temple is called Kumagai-do Hall.
Usually the temple is called Kumagai-do Hall.
Usually the temple is called Kumagai-do Hall.

sen.j: 直実が兜を置いたので蓮池を別名「兜之池」という。
sen.e: Since Naozane placed the helmet of his armor there, Hasuike is also called "Kabutonoike" (Lake of Helmet).
Since Naozane placed the helmet of his armor there, Hasuike is also called "Kabutonoike" (Lake of Helmet).
Since Naozane placed the helmet of his armor there, Hasuike is also called "Kabutonoike" (Lake of Helmet).

sen.j: その後春日局は、池に蓮を植え、堂を改修して名を蓮池院熊谷堂と改称した。
sen.e: Later Kasuga no Tsubone planted lotus in the lake, renovated the hall and renamed it Kumagai-do Hall of Hasuike-in Temple.
Later Kasuga no Tsubone planted lotus in the lake, renovated the hall and renamed it Kumagai-do Hall of Hasuike-in Temple.
Later Kasuga no Tsubone planted lotus in the lake, renovated the hall and renamed it Kumagai-do Hall of Hasuike-in Temple.

sen.j: 直実鎧掛けの松
sen.e: Pine tree from which Naozane hung his armor.
Pine tree over whose branch Naozane hanged his armor.
Pine tree on which Naozane hung his armor.

sen.j: - 直実が鎧を洗いそれを掛けたという松。
sen.e: This is the pine tree from which Naozane is said to have hung his armor after washing it.
This is the pine tree over whose branch Naozane is said to have hung his armor after washing it.
This is the pine tree on which Naozane is said to have hung his armor after washing it.

sen.j: もとの松は枯れたが、それを引き継いだ二代目である。
sen.e: The original pine tree died down; this is the second pine tree succeeding the original tree.
The original pine tree died down; this is the second pine tree succeeding the original tree.
The original pine tree died down; this is the second pine tree succeeding the original tree.

sen.j: 平成15年に京都市指定保存樹。
sen.e: In 2003, it was designated by Kyoto City as a tree for preservation.
In 2003, it was designated by Kyoto City as a tree for preservation.
In 2003, it was designated by Kyoto City as a tree for preservation.

sen.j: 重要文化財
sen.e: Important cultural property

sen.j: 一枚起請文（伝・真筆） 建暦2年（1212年）正月23日に、源智が形見にということで法然に懇願して、念仏の教えを書いてもらったという（「四十八巻伝」45）。
sen.e: Ichimai-kishomon (said to be a genuine work of Honen): It is said that on March 5, 1212, Genchi implored Honen to write teachings of Buddhist invocation as a remembrance (No. 45 of "The Forty-Eight Scrolls" (biographical picture scrolls of Honen)).

sen.j: 熊谷直実（くまがいじろうなおざね、永治元年2月15日（1141年3月24日）- 建永2年9月4日（1207年9月27日））は平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の平家の武将。
sen.e: Naozane KUMAGAI (March 24, 1141-September 27, 1207) was busho (Japanese military commander) of the Taira family who lived during the end of Heian period until the early Kamakura period.
Naozane KUMAGAI (March 24, 1141-September 27, 1207) was busho (Japanese military commander) of the Taira family who lived during the end of Heian period until the early Kamakura period.
Naozane KUMAGAI (March 31, 1141- October 4, 1207) was busho (Japanese military commander) of the Taira family who lived during the end of Heian period until the early Kamakura period.

sen.j: 石橋山の戦い以後、源氏方として戦うことになる。
sen.e: After the Battle of Ishibashiyama, he took the side of the Minamoto clan in the battles that followed.
After the Battle of Ishibashiyama, he took the side of the Minamoto clan in the battles that followed.
After the Battle of Ishibashiyama, he took the side of the Minamoto clan in the battles that followed.

sen.j: 一ノ谷の戦いで平敦盛を討ち取った事で知られている。
sen.e: He is known for killing TAIRA no Atsumori in the Battle of Ichinotani.
He is known for killing TAIRA no Atsumori in the Battle of Ichinotani.
He is known for killing TAIRA no Atsumori in the Battle of Ichinotani.

sen.j: 殺生の虚しさに気付き、以後源平の戦いには参加しなくなる。
sen.e: He realized the hollowness of killing and since then ceased to take part in the Genpei War (war between the Taira and Minamoto clans).
He came to see how empty it was to kill and since then ceased to take part in the Genpei War (war between the Taira and Minamoto clans).
sen.cmt: realized the hollowness of killing → came to see how empty it was to kill
sen.e: He came to see how empty it was to kill and since then ceased to take part in the Genpei War (war between the Taira and Minamoto clans).

sen.j: 法然と出会った後、徐々に敦盛の供養のために出家を模索するようになる。
sen.e: After meeting Honen, he gradually considered becoming a priest for the repose of Atsumori's soul.
After meeting Honen, he gradually considered becoming a priest for the repose of Atsumori's soul.
After meeting Honen, he gradually considered becoming a priest for the repose of Atsumori's soul.

sen.j: 直実はここ黒谷に至り、鎧を洗い、それを松の枝にかけ、馬をつなぎ、法然上人の門を叩いた。
sen.e: Naozane came to the land of Kurodani, where he washed his armor, hung it from the branch of a pine tree, and yoked up his horse; then he sought to be a disciple of Honen Shonin (a term given to a virtuous Buddhist priest).

Naozane came to the land of Kurodani, where he washed his armor, hanged it from a branch of a pine tree, and yoked up his horse; then he sought to be a disciple of Honen Shonin (a term given to a virtuous Buddhist priest).

sen.e: Naozane came to the land of Kurodani, where he washed his armor, hanged it from a branch of a pine tree, and yoked up his horse; then he sought to be a disciple of Honen Shonin (a term given to a virtuous Buddhist priest).

sen.j: 法然に自分の心のうちを話し、出家、そして庵を結び、熊谷直実法師となったという。
sen.e: He spoke to Honen about his thoughts and entered the priesthood; then he built a hermitage and became Kumagai Naozane Hoshi (a term referring to a Buddhist priest).
He spoke to Honen about his thoughts and entered the priesthood; then he built a hermitage and became Kumagai Naozane Hoshi (a term referring to a Buddhist priest).
He spoke to Honen about his thoughts and entered the priesthood; then he built a hermitage and became Kumagai Naozane Hoshi (a term referring to a Buddhist priest).

sen.j: 京都府長岡京市粟生の西山浄土宗の総本山、光明寺 (長岡京市)（こうみょうじ）は、法然を慕い弟子となった蓮生が、建久9年（1198年）に念仏三昧院を建立したことに始まる。
sen.e: Komyo-ji Temple, which is Sohonzan (grand head temple) of Seizan Jodo Sect in Ao, Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture, began with the establishment of Nenbutsu-zanmai-in Temple in 1198 by Rensho, who worshipped Honen and became his disciple.

sen.j: 「四十八巻伝」27では、蓮生は建永2年9月4日（1207年9月27日））に熊谷市の生家で往生したとされる（別説があるがこれが一般的）。
sen.e: According to No. 27 of "The Forty-Eight Scrolls", Rensho passed away on September 27, 1207 at his birthplace in Kumagaya City (although there are other theories, this is the generally accepted theory).

sen.j: 墓所は熊谷寺 (熊谷市)にあるが、遺言により遺骨は、西山の念仏三昧堂（光明寺 (長岡京市)）に安置されたとされる。
sen.e: Although his graveyard was in Yukoku-ji Temple (Kumagaya City), his cremains were placed in Nenbutsu Zanmai-do Temple in Mt. Nishi (Komyo-ji Temple (Nagaokakyo City)) according to his will.

sen.j: - 春日局」とは朝廷から賜った称号で、江戸幕府3代将軍・徳川家光の乳母。

sen.j: 括弧内は何代目かを記す
sen.e: The number in parenthesis indicates the chronological order of hoshu.

sen.j: 法然房源空(1)→勢観房源智(前2)→法蓮房信空(後2)→正信房湛空(3)→求道房恵尋(4)→素月房恵顗(5)→寿観房任空(6)→示観房範空(7)→我観房運空(8)→僧然定玄(9)→佛立恵照国師（僧任等凞）(10)→良秀僧尋(11)→聖深阿縁(12)→僧海等珍(13)→僧秀良玉(14)→威照良真(15)→称譽秀馨(16)→極譽理聖(17)→栄譽永真(18)→西譽雲栖(19)→弘譽伝心(20)→性譽法山(21)→道残源立(22)→看譽源良(23)→縁譽休岸(24)→長譽源然(25)→琴譽盛林(26)→了的(27)→潮呑(28)→忍譽源授(29)→眼譽呑屋(30)→誓譽厳真(31)→檀譽順応(32)→広譽順長(33)→叶譽酋村(34)→通譽◎林(35)→薫譽寂仙(36)→重譽写悦(37)→到譽順教(38)→香譽春沢(39)→鑑譽万竜(40)→法譽智俊(41)→晃譽念潮(42)→到譽潮音(43)→謙譽霊忠(44)→神譽感霊(45)→覚譽霊長(46)→逾譽俊海(47)→禀譽(48)→浄譽原澄(49)→明譽顕海(50)→祐譽天従(51)→宣譽巨道(52)→貫譽学善(53)→住譽密善(54)→在譽祐倫(55)→黒谷定円〘寥譽〙(56)→獅子吼観定〘梁譽〙(57)→佐藤説門〘開譽〙(58)→獅子吼観定〘梁譽〙(59)→秋浦定玄〘静譽〙(60)→吉水賢融〘仏譽〙(61)→大鹿愍成〘深譽〙(62)→郁芳随円〘相譽〙(63)→望月信亨〘昱譽〙(64)→芳井教岸〘道譽〙(65)→川端信之〘源譽〙(66)→渡辺教善〘闡譽〙(67)→千葉良導〘妙譽〙(68)→福井周道〘鑑譽〙(69)→澤崎梁寿〘定譽〙(70)→藤原弘道〘法譽〙(71)→稲岡覚順〘等譽〙(72)→坪井俊映〘仁譽〙(73)→高橋弘次〘満譽〙(74)
sen.e: Honenbo Genku (1)->Seikanbo Genchi (first 2)->Horenbo Shinku (later 2)->Shoshinbo Tanku (3)->Gudobo Keito (4)->Sogetsubo Eke (5)->Suganbo Jinku (6)->Jikanbo Hanku (7)->Gaganbo Unku (8)->Sozen Jogen (9)->Butsuryu Eisho Kokushi (Sonin Nadohiro) (10)->Yoshihide Sojin (11)->Seimi Aen (12)->Sokai Rachin(13)->Soshu Ryogyoku (14)->Iteri Ryoshin (15)->Shoyo Shukei (16)->Gokuyo Risei (17)->Eiyo Eishin (18)->Saiyo Unsei (19)->Koyo Denshin (20)->Seiyo Hozan (21)->Dozan Genryu (22)->Kanyo Genryo (23)->Enyo Kyugan (24)->Choyo Genzen (25)->Kinyo Seirin (26)->Ryoteki (27)->Chodon (28)->Ninyo Genju (29)->Ganyo Donya (30)->Seiyo Ganshin (31)->Danyo Juno (32)->Koyo Juncho (33)->Kyoyo Shuson (34)->Tsuyo Chorin (35)->Kunyo Jakusen (36)->Juyo Shaetsu (37)->Toyo Junkyo (38)->Koyo Shuntaku (39)->Kanyo Manryu (40)->Hoyo Chishun (41)->Koyo Nencho (42)->Toyo Choon (43)->Kenyo Reishi (44)->Shinyo Kanrei (45)->Kakuyo Reicho (46)->Yuyo Shunkai (47)->Rinyo (48)->Joyo Gencho (49)->Meiyo Kenkai (50)->Yuyo Tenju (51)->Senyo Kyodo (52)->Kanyo Gakuzen (53)->Juyo Myozen (54)->Zaiyo Yurin (55)->Kurotani Joen [Ryoyo] (56)->Shishiku Kanjo [Ryoyo] (57)->Sato Zeimon [Kaiyo] (58)->Shishiku Kanjo [Ryoyo] (59)->Shuho Jogen [Seiyo] (60)->Kissui Kenyu [Butsuyo] (61)->Oka Binjo [Shinyo] (62)->Ikuho Zuien [Soyo] (63)->Mochizuki Shinko [Ikuyo] (64)->Hoi Kyogan [Doyo] (65)->Kawabata Nobuyuki [Genho] (66)->Watanabe Kyozen [Senyo] (67)->Chiba Ryodo [Myoyo] (68)->Fukui Shudo [Kanyo] (69)->Sawazaki Ryoju [Joyo] (70)->Fujiwara Hiromichi [Hoyo] (71)->Inaoka Kakujun [Toyo] (72)->Tsuboi Shunei [Jinyo] (73)->Takahashi Koji [Manyo] (74)
sen.cmt: 内容がWeb上と異なっていたので、Web上の内容に修正しました。以下、定訳不明 【正信房】→【Shoshinbo】 【素月房】→【Sogetsubo】 【寿観房任空】→【Suganbo Jinku】 【範空】→【Hanku】 【我観房運空】→【Gaganbo Unku】 【僧然定玄】→【Sozen Jogen】 【僧任等凞】→【Sonin Nadohiro】 【良秀僧尋】→【Yoshihide Sojin】 【聖深阿縁】→【Seimi Aen】 【僧海等珍】→【Sokai Rachin】 【僧秀良玉】→【Soshu Ryogyoku】 【威照良真】→【Iteri Ryoshin】 【称譽秀馨】→【Shoyo Shukei】 【極譽理聖】→【Gokuyo Risei】 【栄譽永真】→【Eiyo Eishin】 【西譽雲栖】→【Saiyo Unsei】 【弘譽伝心】→【Koyo Denshin】 【性譽法山】→【Seiyo Hozan】 【道残源立】→【Dozan Genryu】 【看譽源良】→【Kanyo Genryo】 【縁譽休岸】→【Enyo Kyugan】 【長譽源然】→【Choyo Genzen】 【琴譽】→【Kinyo】 【潮呑】→【Chodon】 【忍譽源授】→【Ninyo Genju】 【眼譽呑屋】→【Ganyo Donya】 【誓譽厳真】→【Seiyo Ganshin】 【檀譽順応】→【Danyo Juno】 【広譽順長】→【Koyo Juncho】 【叶譽酋村】→【Kyoyo Shuson】 【通譽◎林】→【Tsuyo Chorin】 【薫譽】→【Kunyo】 【重譽写悦】→【Juyo Shaetsu】 【到譽順教】→【Toyo Junkyo】 【香譽春沢】→【Koyo Shuntaku】 【鑑譽万竜】→【Kanyo Manryu】 【法譽智俊】→【Hoyo Chishun】 【晃譽念潮】→【Koyo Nencho】 【到譽潮音】→【Toyo Choon】 【謙譽霊忠】→【Kenyo Reishi】 【神譽感霊】→【Shinyo Kanrei】 【覚譽霊長】→【Kakuyo Reicho】 【逾譽】→【Yuyo】 【禀譽】→【Rinyo】 【浄譽原澄】→【Joyo Gencho】 【明譽顕海】→【Meiyo Kenkai】 【祐譽天従】→【Yuyo Tenju】 【宣譽巨道】→【Senyo Kyodo】 【貫譽学善】→【Kanyo Gakuzen】 【住譽密善】→【Juyo Myozen】 【在譽祐倫】→【Zaiyo Yurin】 【寥譽】→【Ryoyo】 【獅子吼観定〘梁譽〙】→【Shishiku Kanjo [Ryoyo]】 【佐藤説門〘開譽〙】→【Sato Zeimon [Kaiyo]】 【秋浦定玄〘静譽〙】→【Shuho Jogen [Seiyo]】 【吉水賢融〘仏譽〙】→【Kissui Kenyu [Butsuyo]】 【大鹿愍成〘深譽〙】→【Oka Binjo [Shinyo]】 【郁芳随円〘相譽〙】→【Ikuho Zuien [Soyo]】 【望月信亨〘昱譽〙】→【Mochizuki Shinko [Ikuyo] 】 【芳井教岸〘道譽〙】→【Hoi Kyogan [Doyo] 】 【川端信之〘源譽〙】→【Kawabata Nobuyuki [Genho]】 渡辺教善〘闡譽〙】→【Watanabe Kyozen [Senyo]】 【妙譽】→【Myoyo】 【福井周道〘鑑譽〙】→【Fukui Shudo [Kanyo] 】 【澤崎梁寿〘定譽〙】→【Sawazaki Ryoju [Joyo] 】 【藤原弘道〘法譽〙】→【Sawazaki Ryoju [Joyo] 】 【稲岡覚順〘等譽〙】→【Inaoka Kakujun [Toyo]】 【仁譽】→【Jinyo 】 【高橋弘次〘満譽〙】→【Takahashi Koji [Manyo]】

sen.j: ※35世の◎は「氵」に「長」。 57世と59世は同一人物。
sen.e: The character for the thirty-fifth head priest consists of氵and長; the fifty-seventh and fifty-ninth head priests are the same.
The character for the thirty-fifth head priest consists of氵and長; the fifty-seventh and fifty-ninth head priests are the same.
